dlgLine.text: Yes?

dlgAnsw.text: I got that wasp spray for you.
Anything that would improve your mood?
Got time for some questions?
It's nothing. I'll talk to you later.

dlgLine.text: Okay.

dlgAnsw.text: How did you get here?
In your opinion, how bad is it out there?
What do you think of me?
What would you say your specialties are?
What do you think would make this place better?
Can you tell me about the other survivors of the crash?
I'm going to take a look around - see ya.

dlgLine.text: <Sigh> I'd really just like to be left alone right now, okay?

dlgAnsw.text: Anything that would improve your mood?
Right. See ya.
If that's what you want. I'll talk to you later.

dlgLine.text: Just leave me alone...

dlgAnsw.text: Fine.
It wasn't my fault. Sorry.

dlgLine.text: I'm really sorry - about your loss...

dlgAnsw.text: Yeah...
I'm really trying not to think about it. I keep hoping I'll wake up.

dlgLine.text: How's your head?

dlgAnsw.text: It's fine.
Shitty.
I'd rather be alone right now. Excuse me.

dlgLine.text: I don't really know what I would do if I lost Mom. Um...
I think we all feel that way lately.
I did the best I could...

dlgAnsw.text: Thanks. I'm grateful.
I wish you had just let me die.

dlgLine.text: It was nothing... well, it was - you were pretty beat up - but I'm just glad I could help.

dlgAnsw.text: Judging from the stiches, humans aren't your specialty.
You're too young to be a doctor - are you studying medicine?
Are you a nurse?
So, how did you end up here...?
We'll talk later.

dlgLine.text: No, um, actually I'm in training to be a veterinarian. If you can tell from my work, you must know a lot more about medicine than me. What a relief! People have been treating me like I'm a doctor and it's terrifying.

dlgAnsw.text: Give yourself some credit - you saved my life.
Don't worry, I'll make sure they consult me first.
You're not trained to handle this type of thing. Leave it to me.

dlgLine.text: Not quite - I'm training to be a doctor.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I was finishing up another semester of vet school when Mom-

dlgAnsw.text: Vet school?
Wait - you're not a doctor?!

dlgLine.text: Um, well... thanks. I guess with the situation being what it is, I need to make use of any knowledge I have.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I can help, I guess - I just can't take the pressure or the responsibility of people's life being in my hands. I'm just not ready - or even trained.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: I'm not saying I can't be useful, but I'd rather someone else with more experience calls the shots.

dlgAnsw.text: - New Answ -

dlgLine.text: That's a horrible thing to say! You don't really believe that?!

dlgAnsw.text: No, I guess not.
You wouldn't understand.
Whatever.

dlgLine.text: You're suffering from something called "Survivor Guilt" - Elaine's experiencing the same thing. You can't punish yourself because you lived... There was something my psych teacher once told us about crash survivors...

dlgAnsw.text: They always think they could have done more, textbook answer. You still in med school?
Are you a doctor?
Whatever - look, I just need to be alone right now. Excuse me.

dlgLine.text: So...

dlgAnsw.text: How did you get here?
In your opinion, how bad is it out there?
What do you think of me?
I'm going to take a look around - see ya.

dlgLine.text: I was at school when Mom just showed up. She was worried about my safety - I guess most people were, but we were too busy with school to notice. Anyhow, Mom - she's a truck driver...

She wanted to drive us back to New Mexico - we've got family there. It was more secure than Baton Rouge, anyhow. Mom's breezed the route plenty of times before, but with all the traffic and then Dallas being cut off, well we were forced onto the backroads.

We were almost out of gas and Mom was trying to find help on the radio - that's when Davis told us about the school. The Splendid police brought us here when the truck died a few miles out. We've been here ever since.

dlgAnsw.text: What would you say your specialties are?
What do you think would make this place better?
I had another question.
Thanks for sharing. See ya later.

dlgLine.text: I saw things on the drive here...This woman darting out in front of a car to have someone take her kid... This duffel bag on the side of the road, squirming around... The sound of the gunshots when people tried to run the roadblocks...
I try not to think about it... as much as that's possible.

dlgAnsw.text: Your mother's just trying to protect you, but I trust you to watch my back out there.
Another question...
I should go. See ya, Renee.

dlgLine.text: I don't know why everyone feels the need to protect me - guess I have that kind of a face or something...

dlgAnsw.text: I had another question.
Stay safe, Renee. Talk to you later.

dlgLine.text: Um... I don't really know you. You're a fast healer? Geez... that's a weird thing to ask.

dlgAnsw.text: Let me try another question...
Yeah, I guess. I should go.

dlgLine.text: Well, they've been having me patch people up here because of my schooling, but people aren't really my specialty.

dlgAnsw.text: You're not a medical student?
It's okay - I'm sure you'll be a real asset.
Have you had to kill anyone?
Got it, thanks. Talk to you later.

dlgLine.text: Yeah. Um... veterinary medicine, actually. I'm not really trained on humans - I keep telling people that, but they keep treating me like a doctor and it's terrifying!

dlgAnsw.text: Let's talk about something else.
Good to know. See ya later.

dlgLine.text: I'll do what I can.

dlgAnsw.text: I had another question.
Good. Talk to you later.

dlgLine.text: NO! God... One time I hit a raccoon with my car and I felt horrible for days - do I sound like a killer to you?

dlgAnsw.text: Sorry, curious. I had another question.
Just asking... I should probably go now.

dlgLine.text: Um... I think I'd feel better if we took in some more people. There's got to be others out there looking for shelter. There's plenty of room here.

dlgAnsw.text: I'll see what I can do. One more thing...
I should get on that. See ya.

dlgLine.text: Great. I'll take care of it tonight, when they're dormant. At least, I hope they will be. That nest has been growing by the day, so this couldn't have come at a better time.

dlgAnsw.text: Careful with that. See ya.
I still wish we could have torched it, but have fun anyhow.

dlgLine.text: There were two. Elaine's been a wreck since they found her at the crash. She was pretty traumatized by something. I've tried everything I know to get to her - maybe you'll have more luck.
The other survivor had worse injuries than you. To be honest - there's not much I can do aside from change his bandages and wait.

dlgAnsw.text: Another question...
I see. Thanks.

dlgLine.text: We should see what Davis has to say.

dlgAnsw.text: Okay.
We'll talk later.

dlgLine.text: I got really addicted to coffee in college - the good stuff, not that freeze-dried junk. I will jury-rig a coffee press if I have to. Otherwise, I could use some rechargeable batteries for my flashlight, so I can read at night.

dlgAnsw.text: I have some whole bean coffee for you.
I have some rechargeable batteries.
I'll let you know if I find anything.

dlgLine.text: Thanks. Just smelling these makes me happy.

dlgAnsw.text: Hope it helps. See ya.
I bet. Enjoy.

dlgLine.text: Great. I'm always running out of juice. I don't know if it's just that studying makes me feel like nothing's changed for me or that I know it'll just make me a better medic here, but it's all I do in my spare time.

dlgAnsw.text: Glad they help. See ya.
I appreciate your responsibility. Talk to you later.
